loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia L. is from the village of Sumalag, Kinoguitan Mis. Oriental. She is 42 years old, married, and has six school-age children. 

Letecia owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop which sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Letecia has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Letecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Letecia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her inventory

loans.name: Abanya

texts.en:
Abanya E. is currently in the business of selling charcoal in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.  Abanya is 35 years old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has four children, and her children go to school.  With the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Tuy S., 45, is married with six children. She resides in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she and her husband sell fruit at a local market.  They earn $11 per day.  Her husband helps his wife in the business daily. Tuy and her husband seek to improve their standard of living by generating a better income. She is asking for a loan of $1000 to purchase fruit from local farmers to resell to her customers. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: Buy fruit to resell.

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es:
La señora Zoila es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa D. Lima - Juli” desD. hace 8 años atrás, del distrito D. Juli, provincia D. Chucuito, departamento D. Puno. Ella tiene 60 años D. edad, estudiò secundaria completa, es casada y tiene 3 hijos.
Zoila se dedica a la compra y venta D. ganado y nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles compró ganado ovino y porcino.
Actualmente solicitará un crédito D. S/. 1,600.00 nuevos soles con los que comprarà un toro.
Su sueño para el futuro es vivir co su esposo D. la mejor manera posible. 
Lo que màs le gusta D. su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y las reuniones, donD. las socias son muy puntuales.
texts.en:
Zoila, 60, has been a member of the "Santa Rosa D. Lima-Juli" communal bank, which is in the Juli district, Chucuito province, Puno department for the past 8 years. She completed secondary school, is married, and has 3 children. She raises cattle. With her first, 300 new sol, loan from the Manuela Ramos Movement, she bought sheep and pigs. Currently, she is requesting 1600 new soles to buy a bull. Her dream for the future is to be able to live as comfortably as possible alongsiD. her husband. What she likes best about her communal bank is the savings and the meetings, where her fellow members are very punctual.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a bull.

loans.name: Florencia Sonia

texts.es: LA Sra. Sonia, es cliente de Emprender desde el año 2004, ella trabajo en grupo solidario "CLAVELITOS"diez secuencias, luego solicito crédito individual con cinco secuencias, la Sra. Sonia trabaja acomodando sombreros y joyas  por la zona de Los Pinos y por Ovejuyo principalmente, ella trabaja como empleada del hogar en la zona Los Pinos, donde tiene su mercado, y donde ella vive, tiene su esposo quien trabaja como chofer asalariado y tambien se dedica a la venta de llantas que trae de Iquique, tienen cuatro hijos en edad escolar, pero dos de ellos trabajan en sus horas libres, la mayor como empleada de limpieza y el otro hijo como voceador, pese a algunos problemas familiares, ella pagó sus cuotas de manera puntual, ambos esposos se colaboran y cumplen con sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Sonia has been a client of Emprender since 2004. She worked with the solidarity group “Clavelitos” for ten loan cycles. She later received five individual loans.

Sra. Sonia sells hats and jewelry primarily in the districts of Los Pinos and Ovejuyo. In addition, she works as a housekeeper in the Los Pinos district, which is also where she lives and where the market she sells is located. Her husband works as a salaried driver and also sells tires that are shipped in from Iquique. They have four school-age children, but two of them also work during their free time. The oldest child cleans houses, while the other child sells newspapers. Despite some family problems, she has been able to pay her loans in a timely manner. She and husband work together so that she is able to make her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN ASUNTA DE RACCHI” de la Asociación Arariwa, tiene 37años, es casada y tiene dos hijos: Ronal tiene 10 años y  Maribell tiene 5 años. Ellos viven en el poblado de Racchí de la provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. Racchí esta a 45 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.
  
Maria vende cereales, hortalizas y tubérculos como papa, cebada, trigo, maíz, tarwi y muchos más productos. Maria nos cuenta sus productos los vende los días viernes y miércoles en el mercado de Urubamba, los días sábados en el mercado de Huancaro del Cusco y los domingos en el mercado de Calca. Maria tiene ganado como por ejemplo 2 toros, 15 chanchos y 30 cuyes que después de alimentarlos y hacer crecer los vende.  Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. 

Maria es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que requiere el préstamo para comprar más semillas de cebada, maíz, papa, cebolla, zanahorias, etc. 
 
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
María, 37, is a member of Asociación Arariwa's “VIRGEN ASUNTA DE RACCHI” communal bank. She is married and has two children: Ronal, 10 and Maribell, 5. They live in Racchí, Urubamba province, Cusco department; Racchí is 45 minutes away from Cusco. María sells cereals, vegetables, and tubers like: potato, barley, wheat, corn, tarwi (an ancient food crop of the Incas, that has been used for centuries in traditional Andean crop rotations. Tarwi seeds are high in protein, 40%, as much as peas, beans, soybeans and peanuts), among many others. María sells her products in Urubamba's market on Wednesdays and Fridays. On Saturdays she sells in the Huancaro market in Cusco, and on Sundays, in Calca's market. María also raises farm animals for sale. For example, she has 2 bulls, 15 pigs and 30 guinea-pigs. She has been in this line of work for several years now and does quite well thanks to the effort she puts into her work. María is a hard-working, enterprising mother who needs funding to buy barley, corn, potato, onion, carrot seed. She is grateful for the opportunity offered to her by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy barley, corn, potato, onion, carrot seed.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel, a 45-year-old married man with two daughters who are both attending school, has been running Sam's Butchery for 11 years, mainly selling beef and mutton and employing one person. He wants to increase his stock with a loan of kes. 70,000. His other source of income is his taxi business. Previously, he was employed in the hotel business. Samuel hopes someday to own a slaughterhouse and supply meat as a wholsaler in the Burma market. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for helping him to expand his business.

loans.use: To increase stock of meat.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa C. is a 33 year-old married woman from Jala-jala, Rizal. She and her husband are blessed to have four children.  A member of the Bayugo center of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) Rizal East Branch, Elisa is a very industrious woman determined to achieve a better life.  Despite hardships caused by poverty, Elisa remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. The love and support of her husband make her life quite meaningful.

To earn a living, Elisa buys and sells fish. She has been engaged in this business for two years. She joined ASHI, a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2005. During the course of her membership, she has been an excellent performer with respect to regular attendance at meetings, loan repayment, and projects. She is now seeking her sixth loan, in the amount of 40,000 PHP, to purchase additional inventory of fish.

With access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, Elisa is hopeful that her dreams of sending her children to a university to complete college degrees will be achieved.  She also hopes to build a more durable house made of concrete, and to purchase a car to support her business.  A vehicle will help with customer deliveries and inventory pick-up at the dock.

Elisa’s desire to give her children a brighter future fuels her dedication to her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory of fish

loans.name: El Tamarindo Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama El tamarindo se llama asi por que las integrantes del grupo se reunen semanalmente bajo un arbol frondoso de tamarindo para que realicen sus pagos.  Esta integrada por 10 personas todas son mujeres y son Rosa , Martha, Maria Magdalena, Araceli, Sacaria, Juana, Dulce Maria, Oralis, Noelia y Lilia todas viven en el municipio de florencio villarreal en el estado de guerrero. Tienen sus pequeños negocios, como Rosa y Martha venden ropa, Maria Magdalena y Margarita tamales, Araceli, Sacaria y Juana compra y venta de pescado, Dulce Maria carniceria, Oralis zapateria, Noelia comida y Lilia perfumes. Todas ellas comenta que se ayudan mucho con sus ventas.

La señora Areceli M. L. tiene 25 años de edad es casada, estudio primaria no la termino pero sabe leer y escribir es madre de 3 hijos el mayor tiene 11 años ya va a terminar la primaria, la otra tiene 10 y 2 años , ella vende pescados en el mercado ya que vive lejos del centro es por eso que renta un local .

Ella comenta que su negocio le da buenos resultados pero es muy pequeño el local es por eso que quiere  prestamo para ampliarlo y adecuarlo a sus necesidades de venta para los clientes y posteriormente remodelar su equipo de trabajo y asi tener mas espacio y mas clientes .
texts.en:
This group is called "El Tamarindo" because the group members meet weekly under a leafy tamarind tree to make their payments. There are 10 members, all of whom are women. They are Rosa, Martha, Maria Magdalena, Araceli, Sacaria, Juana, Dulce Maria, Oralis, Noelia, and Lilia. They all live in the town of Florencio Villarreal in the state of Guerrero. They run their own small businesses. Rosa and Martha sell clothes; Maria Magdalena and Margarita sell tamales; Araceli, Sacaria and Juana buy and sell fish; Dulce Maria runs a butchers shop; Oralis runs a shoe shop; Noelia sells food; and Lilia sells perfume. All of them say that they help a lot with their sales.

Areceli is 25 years old and is married. She did not finish primary school, but she can read and write. She is the mother of 3 children, the oldest is 11 and has finished primary school, and the others are 10 and 2 years old. She sells fish in the market. As she lives far from the town center she rents business premises.

She says that her business gives her good results, but her premises are very small and she wants this loan in order to extend them and adapt them to her needs for selling to her customers and later to remodel her business equipment so she can have more space and more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To extend her business premises

loans.name: Kreum

texts.en:
Mrs. Kreum L. is a 49-year-old farmer. She was married, but divorced her husband when her kids were very young. She has three children who are no longer in school and work. One is a furniture maker, one is a tailor and the other one is a temporary laborer. To pursue a daily revenue, L. has a skill of cooking meals for wedding parties. 

L. will be using her money to buy accessories for her child's furniture-making business.

loans.use: To buy accessories for furniture making

loans.name: Isabelita

texts.en:
Isabelita H. is from the village of Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Isabelita is married and has six school-age children. To make a living, Isabelita owns a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies.  She also owns a trisikad (pedicab) used to transport passengers in the local community. Isabelita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Isabelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Isabelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Isabelita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith N. Okunya started her ready-made clothes business in the year 2001 after quitting her employment as house help. She says the business is doing well and already giving back capital, and she has never regretted her decision. Judith is 33 years of age, married and blessed with 3 children. She lives in Nambale, Busia district.

Judith would like a loan of KShs. 20,000 to expand her business’s stock. Her main future plan is to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her stock

loans.name: Dakan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dakan de l’association Lolo est composé de 4 femmes mariées de la ville de Kimparana, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Dakan vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et au moins 8 enfants. 
Elles pratiquent les activités d’achats et de  ventes de différentes marchandises  telles les condiments alimentaires, les habits, les céréales, etc. 
Elles collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2007 d’où leur 7ème  prêt solidaire, tous les six prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Tata Fabé  qui s’est spécialisée dans la vente de condiments de toutes sortes,  afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle  qui ne cesse d’augmenter, compte  acheter, 90 paquets de maggi,  12 sacs de sel de cuisine, 40 boites de tomates  en pâtes, 2 paquets de poivres, 20kg de l’ail. 
Elle s’approvisionne en gros à San et à Koutiala pour revendre en détail, au comptant, à Kimparana à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes. 
Elle envisage réaliser 32 500FCFA de bénéfice par mois. Les autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser 29500FCFA par mois.
Elle reste convaincue qu’avec le partenariat de Soro Yiriwaso, elle ouvrira une grande boutique dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
The Dakan group of the Lolo association is composed of four married women from the city of Kimparana, in the region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the group live in large, traditional extended families. They came to know each other in their neighbourhood. They are 45 years old on average and have at least eight children. Their business consists of the purchase and sale of different merchandise such as food condiments, clothing, grains, etc. They have been collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso since 2007 and are taking out their seventh group loan; the previous six loans have been repaid in full. Tata Fabé is a specialist in the sale of all type of food condiments. To meet the needs of her growing clientele, she plans to buy 90 packages of maggi, 12 bags of cooking salt, 40 boxes of tomato paste, two packages of pepper, and 20 kg of garlic. She buys her supplies wholesale in San and Koutiala. She resells them in a retail shop in Kimparana on a cash basis to mostly female customers. She expects to have earnings of 32 500 XOF per month. She is convinced that as a Soro Yiriwaso partner, she will open a large shop in the future. The other members of the group expect to have earnings of 29 500 XOF per month.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food condiments

loans.name: Theoung

texts.en:
Theoung V., 48, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples.

V. produces Cambodian noodles for an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is a teacher for a Christian organization, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses.

V. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a new machine for making the noodles. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new machine for making noodles

loans.name: Tamaraneh Group

texts.en:
Isatu C. (third from left) is the leader of this group. Isatu was born in Sanda village, Northern Sierra Leone. She is approximately 45 years of age, married to a businessman, and they have five children – two in secondary school, two in primary school and one in college. Isatu sells rice and palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil). With the help of this loan, she will buy rice and palm oil wholesale to add to her business.

In the photo are members of the "Tamaraneh" Group and loan officer, Daniel Banya, on the left, handing over the loan. They are small scale businesspeople in the northern city of Makeni. They have applied for a loan from SMT, a partner of Kiva.org. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses and make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living conditions will improve: they will at least be able to provide three meals a day for their children, pay their school fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills in case any of them falls sick.

loans.use: To buy rice and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn B. is a 31-year-old married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa. She and her husband have a 7-year-old child. To earn a living, she and her husband are engaged in the farming business, and they have been doing so for eight years now. Specifically, they plant rice crops. While her husband performs the primary farming duties, she is the one who sells their harvest at the market. She also makes sure that her family is healthy and happy, and she saves for her child's education.

In 2005, Analyn joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, she was able to engage in business activities and to thereby help improve her standard of living. Analyn is now requesting a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($350), which would be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. Notably, this loan would be the eighth loan taken out by Analyn from CEVI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from their business as a result of the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About CEVI: CEVI has increased its portfolio significantly over the past few years. Based in Bohol, CEVI has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training, all of which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Apolonia

texts.en:
Apolonia L. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 57 years old, widowed, and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Apolonia owns and operates a business buying and selling rice and dried fish in the local community. Apolonia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Apolonia joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: José David

texts.es: José David C. de 47 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Usulután, vive junto a sus padres y una pequeña sobrina. José posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos de primera necesidad y productos comestibles como: granos básicos, productos lácteos, pan, aceite y otros más los cuales vende por mayor, el negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitación en donde cuenta con muchos clientes, los cuales compran sus productos para surtir negocios más pequeños. José es una persona muy dedicada a su trabajo quien se esfuerza mucho por sostener a sus padres y a su sobrina, así como también todos los gastos del hogar, sus padres son de edad bastante avanzado pero a pesar de esto le ayudan a atender el negocio, sobre todo en horas pico que hay bastantes clientes. José solicita un préstamo con el fin de poder comprar productos nuevos, los cuales aún no posee, como también comprar productos como harina, aceite, granos básicos, productos lácteos y otros más los cuales poseen mayor demanda, esto le permitirá percibir mayores ganancias y así mismo mantener estable su negocio.
texts.en:
José David C., who is 47, lives in the Usulután district with his parents and a small niece. José has a small store in which he sells basic necessities and food products such as basic grains, dairy products, bread, oil, and other items that he sells wholesale. The business is located in his home, where he has many customers who buy his products to stock smaller businesses. José is a person who is very dedicated to his work and who makes a great effort to support his parents and his niece, as well as covering all the household expenses. His parents are of a rather advanced age, but in spite of this they help him tend his business, especially at peak hours when there are a lot of customers. José is applying for a loan so that he can buy new products that he still doesn't have and also buy products like flour, oil, basic grains, dairy products, and others items which are in great demand. This will permit him to increase his earnings and at the same time to keep his business steady.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products that are basic necessities

loans.name: Ulviyya

texts.en:
Ulviyya A. is 20 years old. She is married with one baby. Ulviyya sells women's clothes. She has been in this business almost a year. Ulviyya has very good taste, and she is always ready to advise her customers on which clothes to choose for this or that occasion. That is why she has her constant customers. Moreover, Ulviyya’s prices are attractive for various levels of the population, as she has a wide range of goods for any taste and wallet. Her monthly profit is 200-300 AZN.
 
She hopes that she can continue developing her business. Now, Ulviyya needs 600 AZN to purchase new clothes in order to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.use: To purchase new clothes

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
A hardworking entrepreneur, Nancy D. C. has run a fishing and fish trading business for almost 10 years from the village of Nauring, Pandan in the province of Antique, earning her a reasonable monthly profit. Nancy’s main challenge is her small amount of stock because she only has a small amount of working capital to put into her fishing business. 

She joined ASHI, a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2003 and is very grateful for secured access to capital and other services such as savings and insurance. Now Nancy wants to request a larger loan for their growing fishing business. Nancy will sell the fish her husband catches in their village and to some people wanting to sell fish in the market. She thinks that commercializing her fishing business and expanding it will enable her to earn more revenue and be able to pay school fees for her children and cater to the other family needs. With access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, Nancy is hopeful her dreams of sending her children to a university to complete college degrees will be achieved. Nancy’s wishes to give her children a brighter future fuel her commitment to her fishing business. 

With all of her plans for the growth of her business, Nancy would be happier if her children are able to achieve their personal dreams and have their own life out of poverty.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her growing fishing business.

loans.name: Paula Moserrate

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Amor Y Paz se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Calderón de la  ciudad de Portoviejo, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos.

La señora Paula tiene 36 años y está casada hace 20 años, tiene 4 hijos el mayor estudia en la Universidad, y los otros dos  en colegio, uno de sus hijos falleció hace dos años atrás, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura.

Se dedica junto a su esposo y  sus hijos a la agricultura y a la venta de sus productos, cultivan plátano, yuca, y maní.  Venden estos productos y derivados de estos como el almidón. Trabajan en el campo desde las siete hasta las tres de la tarde, y sus productos los lleva a vender a Manta, Chone y Portoviejo, los fines de semana en los que dedican casi todo el día. Trabajan con ellos seis personas a los cuales les pagan su jornal para su sustento.

Este nuevo crédito lo va a utilizar en comprar mas productos e insumos para la agricultura además de almidón ya que este se vende a buen precio en la ciudad. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el principio, es socia fundadora y le gusta por la ayuda que ha recibido.
 
Sus metas son que sus hijos sean profesionales y mejorar día a día.
texts.en:
The “Amor y Paz” (Love and Peace) communal bank meets every two weeks in Portoviejo’s Calderón parish. Most of the residents of this location are farmers and raise animals to sell. Paula, 36, has been married for 20 years and has had four children. The oldest is in the University and the other two are in school. One of her children died two years ago. Her husband is a farmer. She, her husband and her children work in farming and sell what they grow. They farm bananas, manioc and peanuts. They sell these products and derivatives of them, like tapioca starch. They work the fields from 7am until 3pm and they take their products to Manta, Chone and Portoviejo to sell on weekends spending most of the day selling. They have six employees who they pay a daily wage for their support. This new loan will be used to buy more farming supplies as well as more tapioca starch because it sells for a good price in the city. She has been in the communal bank since its inception; she’s a founding member an she likes it because of the help she has received. Her goals are that her children become professionals and to improve day by day.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy some farming supplies and some tapioca The “Amor y Paz” (Love and Peace) communal bank meets every two weeks in Portoviejo’s Calderón parish.  Most of the residents of this location are farmers and raise animals to sell.starch.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand and progress her business.

loans.name: Maria De Pilar

texts.es:
María del Pilar es una madre de familia de 24 años de edad que reside junto a su esposo y a su menor hijo en el Centro Poblado Menor Callanca del distrito de Monsefú, la zona se encuentra ubicada a veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la confección y bordado de manteles y faldas. Ella cuenta con una máquina de coser con la cual realiza su trabajo en base a pedidos. El trabajo requiere de mucha creatividad y paciencia. Su actividad cuenta con buena acogida debido a que las prendas que elabora están hechas con artículos de calidad y sus diseños son bastante bonitos. Su esposo trabaja como peón agrícola y adicionalmente comercializa cerdos. Con los ingresos que ambos perciben tratan siempre de salir adelante y progresar.

María desea adquirir algunos insumos para elaborar más bordados y además realizar algunas mejoras en su vivienda. Por ello ha decidido solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

María es una mujer con muchas ganas de progresar y salir adelante. Las personas que le conocen en la zona le tienen mucha confianza y estima.
texts.en:
María del Pilar is a 24-year-old mother who lives with her husband and young son in the town of Menor Callanca in the district of Monsefú.  This area is 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

She makes a living by making embroidered tableclothes and skirts.  She has a sewing machine that she uses to do her work, for which she takes orders.  Her work requires a lot of creativity and patience.  Her work is well-received because the items she makes are of high quality, and her designs are very pretty.  Her husband works as an agricultural worker and also raises pigs.  With the income that they both make, they try to always get ahead.

María hopes to acquire some supplies to embroider more items and to make some improvements to her home.  This is why she has decided to request a loan for the first time from Edpyme Alternativa for 1500 PEN.

María is a woman who wants very much to get ahead.  The people that know her in the area have a lot of confidence in her and hold her in high regard.

loans.use: To acquire supplies to embroider more items and to make some improvements to her home.

loans.name: Kavata

texts.en:
Kavata is 27 years old and married to Fidelis. She supports the family alone while her spouse goes to college. They have one child who is five years old. She has been running the beauty salon for four years now with monthly profit of approximately KES 10,000. 

She has never been in another MFI and this is her first loan from KADET. She intends to buy a stock of children clothes for her salon. She hopes to improve the living standard of her family members.

loans.use: To buy a stock of children clothes

loans.name: Kelegna Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe KELEGNA sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et de 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Massabla-coura de la ville de BOUGOUNI, (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali.) Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de voisinage et de commerce. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles de plus en plus croissantes et exigeantes, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe et tous les deux prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt KOUMBA D., compte acheter, des chargements de charrettes en charbon de bois auprès des paysans producteurs. Elle effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit, au marché et à domicile, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé dans l’activité et l’autre partie dans les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The women of the KELEGNA group are all married and are, on average, 26 years old with two children. They live in traditional large families in the neighborhood of Massabla-coura in the city of BOUGOUNI (third largest region in the republic of Mali). These women known each other through the community as well as business.

In order to better satisfy their customers whom are both growing in size and becoming more exacting in their demands, these women have decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are currently on their third group loan after having correctly reimbursed the previous two.
 
With this loan KOUMBA D. plans to purchase bulk quantities of wood charcoal from countryside producers. She then sells the charcoal both for cash as well as credit, in the markets and from her home, to both male and female customers. With this loan she hopes to make a monthly profit of 65,000 FCFA [approximately USD $ 136 ] to reinvest in her business as well as provide for her family.

loans.use: Purchasing wood charcoal

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites P. is from the village of Aguinaldo Cordon. She is 36 years old. Marites is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she  plants and harvests fruits and vegetables to sell. She also manages a hog raising business. Marites has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Phillip K. Rono is a 42-year-old farmer. He is married with five children between 7 and 18 years of age. He is a small-scale Maize farmer and also keeps poultry.

Phillip has been in business for the last 13 years. From this business he gets a profit of Kshs 2,000 a month. He has borrowed a third loan of Kshs 35,000, of which he intends to use Kshs 5,000 to buy seeds, Kshs 8,000 for fertilizer, Kshs 12,000 for wages, Kshs 5,000 for transport and Kshs 5,000 for other overhead costs.
   
Phillip anticipates using his profits to pay school fees for his children and expand his business. His dream is to educate his children, improve their living standard through better provision of food and clothing, and also expand his business.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers and pay for wages, transport, and other overhead costs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more maize for kenkey business.

loans.name: On's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. On S. earns her living by selling food in her village. Her husband, Mr. Phorn Hnork, is a bodyguard. Due to their careers not earning enough income to support the family, Mrs. On S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase groceries to sell. With her new business, she hopes that she will increase their income to improve the family's living conditions. This couple has a child who is attending a local school. 

This village bank includes ten members from Damnak Sangkae village in Kandal province. They selected Mrs. On S., 42 years old, as the village bank president. With their loans, they hope to increase their income to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Orquidia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Orquídea es mujer comerciante, madre de dos hijos, cuenta con su propio negocio una pulpería que ha crecido gracias al esfuerzo y financiamiento que la institución ha dado, en donde ha aumentado su inventario y sus niveles de ventas.
Inicio  con fondos propios, con liquidación de su trabajo, a si mismo con el apoyo económico de su esposo, quien labora como cadete de taxi.
Con este nuevo préstamo invertirá en productos de consumo como: quintales de arroz, frijoles, azúcar, maíz, bidón de aceite, caja de jabón, cereales, golosinas, productos lácteos, pollo y otros productos que sastifagan al cliente. Siendo el objetivo vender para poder cubrir sus gastos básicos, como sus compromisos de pago.
texts.en:
Orquídea is a business woman, and mother of two children, she has her own business - a local store - which has grown thanks to the effort and financing that the institution has given, and where she has increased her stock and her sales levels.
She started with her own funds, with the sale of her own business, and with the financial support of her husband who works as a taxi driver.
With this new loan she will invest in consumer products like: kilos of rice, beans, sugar, corn, cans of oil, cakes of soap, cereals, candy, milk products,chicken and other products that the customers need. The objective being to make sales to be able to cover her basic costs, like her payment obligations.

loans.use: She will buy consumer products to increase her sales levels

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. sells fried fish and banku (a staple in Ghana made of a mix of fermented corn and cassava dough) at Abbrem Agona near Aburam, Cape Coast. Abena has received junior high education. She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a carpenter. 

Abena has been selling fried fish and banku for 7 years. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy bags of corn and other ingredients to cook banku for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy bags of corn and other ingredients to cook banku for sale.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita is a married woman who lives in Escalante City, Negros Occidental.  She earns her living by operating a dried fish vending business and a sari-sari (general) store. Her husband Gregorio, who is 60 years old, helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children who are 13 to 19 years old. Angelita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Angelita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for the future education of their children. Angelita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Honorato

texts.es: Honorato, de 45 años de edad, natural del distrito de Kimbiri. Por problemas familiares vive separado de su pareja y esta al cuidado de sus cuatro queridos hijos y juntos viven en su casa propia en el distrito de kimbiri departamento de Cusco. Honorato es el pilar de sus hijos, para él no hay impedimentos para seguir surgiendo y obteniendo buenos provechos en la vida y cumple un rol de padre y madre dentro de su cesta familiar. Desde muy niño sus padres le inculcaron a trabajar en la chacra, es campesino y cuenta con 04 hectáreas de terreno cultivado con plantaciones de Piña, café y hojas de coca, que son plantas oriundas de la zona selvática del Valle Río Apurimac. Viene trabajando 23 años en sus propias tierras, y en tiempos de cosecha cuenta  con el apoyo de sus hijos y de los jornaleros para avanzar con mayor rapidez con las extracciones de los frutos. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cosechar los frutos de las plantas; ya que así siente que los meses de arduo trabajo le brindan como recompensa la calidad de sus frutos. Considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus productos desde la chacra hasta la ciudad de san francisco; lugar donde le ofrecen mejores precios por sus productos. El crédito solicitado es para poder comprar más semillas de piña y poder renovarlos por las plantas de café; por que los frutos de piña le generan mayor ingreso y en menor tiempo. En adelante desea comprar nuevas tierras para expandir sus sembríos y aumentar su producción. Este su segundo crédito de con MFP, sabe que si lo paga a tiempo, podrá acceder a otro crédito con mayor tranquilidad y sin traerle complicaciones a su banco comunal. Con los 2,000 nuevos soles solicitados, comprará más semillas de  piña para remplazar por los de café; por que los frutos de la piña le generan mayor ingreso y en menor tiempo.
texts.en:
Honorato, age 45, is a native of the District of Kimbiri.  Due to family problems, he lives apart from his partner and cares for their four beloved children.  They live in their own home in the District of Kimbiri in the Department of Cusco.  Honorato is a pillar for his children.  For him there are no obstacles to prevent him from continuing forward and obtaining good benefits out of life.  He must play the role of both father and mother in order to support his family.  When he was a young boy, his parents taught him how to work on a farm.  Honorato is a farmer and has four hectares of land on which he grows pineapples, coffee, and coca leaves.  These crops are native to the tropical region of the Apurimac River Valley.  He has worked on his land for 23 years.  During the harvest season, he has the help of his children and from workers who can pick the fruit with great speed.  What he enjoys most about his job is harvesting the fruit from his plants.  He feels rewarded for the months of hard work whenever his harvest results in quality fruit.  Honarato considers the most difficult part to be transporting his products from the farm to the city of San Francisco, the place that offers the best prices for his products.  

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy more pineapple seedlings to replace his coffee plants.  Pineapples generate more income and require less time to grow.  Going forward he wants to buy more land so that he can expand his crops and increase production.  This is his second loan with MFP.  He knows that he must submit his payments on time so that he can access another loan more easily and not create complications for his Communal Bank.  The loan of 2000 PEN that he requested will be used to buy more pineapple seedlings in place of coffee so that he can earn more income in less time.

loans.use: To purchase pineapple seedlings.

loans.name: Rosa Isela

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Isela C. tiene ya más de un año con su negocio de venta de papelería escolar.
Esta solicitando un préstamo ya que le esta haciendo falta más equipo y mercancía, pero no cuenta con el capital necesario para invertir en el negocio y así poder satisfacer las necesidades de su clientes.
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias del negocio, ya que su esposo el señor Mauricio Bautista se encargará de los gastos familiares y necesidades de sus tres hijos, con el ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo, como chofer de un camión de carga.
texts.en:
Rosa Isela C. has been working for more than a year in her business selling school supplies.  She is requesting a loan since she needs to buy more equipment and merchandise but doesn't have the necessary capital to invest in her business.  She needs to do this in order meet her customers' needs.

Rosa plans to repay her loan with the profits that she makes from her business since her husband, Mauricio Bautista, will take care of their family expenses and the needs of their three children with the income he makes from his job as a truck driver.

loans.use: to buy computer equipment for her business

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
María, reside en San Rafael Oriente, departamento de San Miguel, tiene 26 años de edad, vive con su esposo y dos hijos una de 6 y otra de 3 años de edad, se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, este negocio lo inicio junto a su esposo, no tienen un horario fijo y hoy día posee una gran experiencia.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para la compra  de cerdos pequeños, de los cuales crecerá y engordara para comercializarlos, la inversión le permitirá ampliar la granja y mejorar las ventas futuras.
Su objetivo en incrementar los ingresos a tevés del negocio de los cerdos, y ofrecer un mejor futuro a sus familiares.
texts.en:
Maria, a 26-year-old resident of San Rafael Oriente in the department of San Miguel, lives with her husband and two daughters, ages 6 and 3. She works raising pigs, a business which she began with her husband; she is now quite experienced in the business.

Maria is applying for a loan to buy young piglets, which she will raise and fatten for sale. This investment will allow her to expand her herd and improve her future sales. Her goal is to offer a better future to her family through increasing her income through her pig business.

loans.use: to buy piglets.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Angela Eva

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Nuevo Amanecer se reúne en el sitio Bajo de Montecristi en la provincia de Manabí, es un pequeño lugar rodeado de mucha vegetación, sus habitantes se dedican a diferentes actividades como comerciantes y empelados de fabricas.

La señora Ángela es socia fundadora del Banco comunal hace 15 años y le gusta porque siempre le han ayudado con los créditos. Tiene 75 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen doce hijos, todos son mayores de edad y dos  de ellos aun vive con ella. Su esposo  es anciano y no trabaja.

Ella tiene una tienda de comestibles en su casa en la cual vende todo tipo de productos, como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, etc. trabaja todos los días desde las 7h00 hasta las 18h00, sus hijos le  ayudan cuando están desocupados, los productos los compra en Montecristi y algunos los  recibe en su local. Nos cuenta que lleva 15 años con su negocio el mismo tiempo que entro en el banco ya que con el primer crédito empezó su negocio y esta muy agradecida con la institución.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad.
 
Sus sueños son tener buena salud y seguir adelante.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Nuevo Amanecer" holds its meetings in Bajo de Montecristi in the province of Manabí. It is a small place surrounded by plush vegetation and its inhabitants are involved in different business activities, some being merchants and others factory workers.

Mrs. Ángela is a founding member of the communal bank which she has been part of for 15 years.  She likes belonging to the bank because of the loans it has always helped her with.  She is 75 years old, married and has 12 children, who are all adults.  Two children still live at home.  Her husband is retired.

She has a small grocery store in her home and sells all kinds of products such as rice, sugar, oil and detergent, among other things. She works every day  from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. and her children help her when they are not busy. She purchases her products in Montecristi and some are delivered to her. For 15 years she has been in business, the same length of time she's been in the communal bank.  She used the first loan to get started and she is very grateful to the institution.

This loan will be used to stock the store with more goods such as rice, sugar, oil, detergent, sausage and other basic needs items. 

Her goal is to stay healthy and get ahead.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, detergent, oil, sausage and other basic needs products

loans.name: Elza

texts.es:
Elza nació en el distrito de Caicay de provincia  de la Paucartambo del departamento del Cusco, ella tiene 55 años edad y tiene cuatro hijos, actualmente ella vive en la comunidad donde nació. Elza y su esposo Rómulo tienen un taller de estructuras metálicas y soldadura. Ya son tres años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que le pone en su trabajo. Con  su próximo préstamo, Elza requiere el préstamo para comprar materiales como por ejemplo lijas, fierros, pintura, masilla, etc. 

Elza pertenece al banco comunal “Mamacha del Carmen” de la Asociación Arariwa. El banco comunal esta en el tercer año de funcionamiento y les va muy bien.
texts.en:
Elza was born in the district of Caicay, which is in the province of Paucartamvo in the department of Cusco. She is 55 years old, and has four children. At present, she lives in the community in which she was born. Elza and her husband Rómulo have a workshop for producing metallic structures and welding. They have spent three years dedicated to this business, and it has gone well thanks to the determination they put into their work. Elza needs this loan to buy materials, such as sandpaper, iron, paint, putty, etc. 

Elza belongs to the Mamacha del Carmen Community Bank, which is part of Asociación Arariwa. The community bank is three years old, and is doing well.

loans.use: to buy materials, such as sandpaper, iron, paint, putty, etc.

loans.name: Elman

texts.en:
Elman is 51 years old. He has 8 years of experience in the beef business. His wife is a housekeeper and Elman is the sole breadwinner in his family. Due to this way of life, this father works hard every day to support his family with the best quality of life he can afford.

His butcher shop supplies large amounts of meat to the population of his city. Elman buys cattle in the market and sells their fresh meat daily to his customers. Due to high demand, this man seeks a loan of 1,000 AZN to invest in more cattle so he can have enough product to meet his customers' demands.

loans.use: to purchase more beef to sell

loans.name: Antonio Beltrán

texts.es:
Este cliente  tiene su domicilio  en  ciudad de Managua capital, el  señor Antonio Beltran  se ha caracterizado por ser una `persona honrada  trabajadora con buenos valores y principios  morales como persona, debido a que ha sabido  ganarse el aprecio de todos sus  compañeros de trabajo. 
Se presento ante esta oficina  de  Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para ser invertido en mejoramiento  su vivienda como  enladrillar su casa ya que actualmente es de suelo invertirá en la compra de materiales de construcción,  cerámica,  cemento boom para porcelana  y  pago de  mano obra, y darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
This client has his address in the capital city of Managua.  Antonio Beltran has stood out as an honest, hard working person with good personal values and moral principles having won over the esteem of his coworkers.

He came by this Ceprodel office to request a loan that will be used for home improvements like installing tile flooring since the floor is currently dirt.  He will buy building materials and supplies:  tile, porcelain adhesive, and will pay labor costs to provide his family with a better quality of life.

loans.use: to do some home improvements.

loans.name: Sara Del Socorro

texts.es:
El negocio de Sara, es la venta de ropa de segunda mano y venta de pescado el cual lleva dos años, con el objetivo de ayudar a su familia con los gastos.  Su esposo labora como conductor y ambos están al pendiente de sus dos hijos, los cuales cursan la primaria.
Los pescados un vecino se los vende, a precios accesible, el cual los alza en el frízer de la refrié y casi todos son encargados. Moviendo a si su capital.
Sara lleva cinco ciclos de préstamo en Afodenic el cual ha logrado realizar mejoras a su casa, a si como el aumento de inventario. Con este nuevo  préstamo será para la compra de una paca mixta, dos docena de sandalia de mujer, dos docenas de camisetas de varón y seguir ofertando sus productos el cual tiene algunos de encargo. y desea satisfacer a sus clientes, teniendo poca ropa que espera lograr mejores resultados con esta nueva inversion.
texts.en:
Sara's business is selling second-hand clothes.  She also sells fish.  She has been in this business for two years.  Her goal is to help her family with their expenses.  Sara's husband works as a driver and both of them are alert to the needs of their two children who are in elementary school.  Sara buys her fish from a neighbor at an affordable price.  She keeps them in a freezer and sells nearly all of them to order.  This is how she moves her capital.

Sara has been through five loan cycles with Afodenic and has managed to make some improvements to her home and also increase her stock.  She will use this loan to buy a mixed bundle of clothes: two dozen pairs of women's sandals and two dozen men's t-shirts, so that she can continue selling her products, some of which she has orders for.  She hopes to be able to satisfy her customers.  Sara doesn't have many clothes to sell and hopes to achieve better results with this new investment.

loans.use: to buy a bundle of clothes, sandals and men's t-shirts, to increase her sales

loans.name: Buyanjargal

texts.en:
Buyanjargal lives with his wife and three children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in Uvs province in Mongolia. His older two children attend the local secondary school.

With the help of his wife, Buyanjargal runs a cobbler's shop in his town. They started their business in 2007 and gained much experience. In addition, they began working at a private company in order to supplement their earnings. Buyanjargal earns 350,000 MNT a month while his wife earns 400,000 MNT.

Now Buyanjargal and his wife have many regular customers who purchase many shoes at a time. With their earnings they bought a plot of land on which they can build a house in the future. Buyanjargal is requesting a 400,000 MNT loan to purchase equipment for his business. He is a kind man who says, "I want to buy new equipment in order to increase my sales."

loans.use: To purchase new cobbler's equipment.

loans.name: Hermelinda

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “REYNA D. LOS ANGELES D. URQUILLOS”; el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito D. Urquillos en la Provincia D. Calca y Departamento D. Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Hermelinda; la socia tiene 58 años D. edad, la socia es casada; La socia tiene 3 hijos; la socia se dedica a la agricultura como actividad principal, la socia alterna su actividad económica con la venta D. verduras ella venD. todo tipo D. verduras tales como tomate, brócoli, coliflor, habas, arvejas, zanahoria, cebollas, lechuga; la socia venD. al por mayor también maíz, cuando está fresco venD. en calidad D. choclo, cuando está madura termina D. secar y se venD. como maíz o granos secos. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra D. semilla D. maíz para la siembra.

La socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir D. manera disciplinada con los pagos D. las cuotas.
texts.en:
Hermelinda is a member of the "Reyna D. los Ángeles D. Urquillos" community bank which is located in Urquillos district, in Calca province, in Cusco department.

Hermelinda is 58 years old, married, and has three children.  Her main business activity is farming but she also sells vegetables.  She sells all sorts of vegetables such as tomatoes, broccoli, cauliflower, beans, peas, carrots, onions and lettuce.  She sells corn wholesale.  She sells fresh corn and, when it is ripe, she also dries it and sells it as dried corn kernels.

Hermelinda is requesting this loan to invest in buying corn seed to sow.  She is grateful for the support that she is being given and pledges to make her repayments in a disciplined manner.

loans.use: to invest in buying corn seed to sow

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is a skillful lady who does sewing for her neighboring clients. She receives regular orders and makes good profits every month from her skills. She is 30 years old and has three children. All of them are very young and studying. 

Her husband works in a factory. His income is not enough for the whole family that’s why Nasreen decided to support him financially with her sewing business. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her business sewing clothes. With the loan, she will buy an electric sewing machine that will allow her to finish her orders quicker and earn better profits. She is very much experienced in her work and has been operating her business for the last three years. She is confident that an investment will bring even better profits to her and help her family to live a better financial life. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. She is very responsible client and has established a good credit behavior in the previous loan year.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine for sewing business.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Srey, 46 year old, is a housewife. Her husband is a construction worker with an income of $5 per day. She has three children. Two of her children are studying ,and one is working in the factory with an income of $2.5 per day. Every month, she has to spend $100 on food, $5 on electricity, $10 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy grocery goods to sell at a primary school. This loan will help her to get a career that can help her husband to make income for supporting the family.

loans.use: To buy grocerty goods to sell

loans.name: Reyna

texts.es:
Reyna, D. 55 años, es una mujer muy alegre, esta casada ya varios años, vive en casa propia junto a su esposo y un nieto quien esta con ella.El trabajo D. Reyna consiste en realizar costura en su casa, lleva este trabajo desD. muy niña, ella aprendió a coser porque su madre le enseñó todo sobre este arte y desD. ahí se dedicó a trabajar en esta actividad. Reyna trabaja hace sola y esta contenta D. trabajar en eso.
A ella le gusta todo D. su trabajo, siempre esta alegre ya que gana dinero haciendo costura, siempre tiene clientes y eso le genera muy buenas ganancias, espera poder seguir así con su trabajo ya que siente que se siente bien.Este es el sexto préstamo entre Reyna y la institución MFP, se siente muy bien en el grupo que esta, además ella agradece mucho a Prisma por la oportunidad D. trabajar que le dan a través D. los préstamos otorgados.Con el monto solicitado 1500 soles, ella comprará materiales para su taller y así poder seguir produciendo más.
texts.en:
Reyna, age 55, is a very cheerful woman. She has been married for several years and lives in her own home with her husband and a grandson. Her work involves sewing at home. Reyna has been performing this type of work since she was a young girl. Her mother taught her everything about this art, so she decided to pursue this line of work. Reyna works alone and is happy to do so.

She enjoys every aspect of her work. Reyna is happy to earn her livelihood through sewing. She always has customers, which is why she generates a good income. Reyna hopes to continue in her work as long as she feels well.

This is her sixth loan with MFP. Reyna is glad to be part of her group. She is extremely grateful to MFP for the opportunity to work by providing her loans. With this loan amount of 1500 PEN that she requested, Reyna will buy materials for her workshop so that she can continue producing more.

loans.use: to buy materials for her sewing workshop.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “QORIMANCACHA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco,  y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Francisca; ella tiene 52 años de edad y es casada y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende arroz, azúcar, aceite, leche y fideos, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m, por medio de este negocio saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar arroz, azúcar, leche y fideos al por mayor.

 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Francisca belongs to the “QORIMANCACHA” communal bank, which is located in the Cusco district, within the province and department of the same name.

Francisca is 52 years old, married, and has 4 children. She splits her daily activities with her grocery store business, where she sells rice, sugar, oil, milk, and noodles. She works from 8:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m. She is able to help her children get ahead through her business, which is why she would like to expand it. 

Francisca will use the loan to buy wholesale rice, sugar, milk, and noodles. She is happy to have the loan and is committed to making all of her payments.

loans.use: to buy wholesale rice, sugar, milk, and noodles.

loans.name: Sameera

texts.en:
Sameera is a 42-year-old married woman who has six sons and three daughters. One of her sons is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a modest salary. 
Sameera has her own project, which is making dusters for sale. In this way, she shares with the family in meeting life's expenses. Sameera wants to purchase raw materials for making dusters, but the amount of money she has isn't enough. Therefore, she wants to take a loan of $500 from Kiva partner, FATEN. When Sameera takes the loan, which is to be repaid on a monthly basis, she will purchase the required raw materials and produce more dusters to sell. This will increase her income and enable her to have better living conditions. 
Sameera is photographed holding one of the dusters that she makes.

loans.use: to purchase raw material to produce dusters to sell.

loans.name: Kholmurod

texts.ru: Холмурод проживает в городе Душанбе. Он женат. Ему 60 лет. У него один ребенок. Его сын предоставляет услугу, такси. Сам он работает в ООО "Спецтехника". Он берет кредит для продвижения деятельности сына. В основном для ремонта его машины.
texts.en: Kholmurod lives in the city of Dushanbe.  He is 60 years old, married and has one child.  His son provides a taxi service.  Kholmurod works for a a company called "Spetstekhnika" LLC.  He is requesting this loan for his son's business, primarily for repairs to his car.

loans.use: to make repairs to his car

loans.name: Sadelyn

texts.en:
Sadelyn is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy materials for maintaining her fishing boat.

Sadelyn has been in this business for 13 years. Sadelyn earns more income from a computer shop.

Sadelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy materials to maintain her fishing boat

loans.name: C18516 Dufatanye Group

texts.en:
Flavie, a 33-year-old widow with four children between the ages of 5 and 12 years, is the leader of this group which is called "Dufatanye." Flavie is the first woman on the left in the photo. The operator of a retail shoe business for about six years experience, she works from 7 a.m. until 5 p.m. every day.

Flavie and her team have requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses by purchasing more shoes to sell. They will reinvest the additional profits into their enterprises and pay their children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase more quantity of shoes.

loans.name: Natela

texts.en: Natela is 47 years old and lives in the Gardabani, Kartli region of Georgia with her husband Elvar and 23-year-old son. Elvar works as teacher in a local school, and the entire family works on the family's farm, a three hectare plot of land where they grow broom. Natela uses the crop to make brooms, which she sells in her nation's capital, Tbilisi. The family earns about 1,100 Laris a month. Natela is applying for this loan to hire seasonal help, which will allow her to increase the size of her crop and, with it, her family's income.

loans.use: to hire seasonal help to work on her farm.

loans.name: Mayrambu

texts.ru: Майрамбу 58 лет, замужем.  Основная деятельность семьи Майрамбу – это откорм и перепродажа скота и полеводство.  Начатое еще в 1972 году,  в  период Советского Союза со стартовой суммой в 120 советских рублей хозяйство сегодня приносит около 10,000 сом (KGS) в месяц.   В данный момент, семья Майрамбу обрабатывает 1,74 га орошаемой земли , где выращивают картофель и многолетние травы. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Майрамбу обратилась в компанию «Бай  Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительного скота. Это позволит ей увеличить своей хозяйство и приумножить поголовье скота, сделав, таким образом по ее мнению, наилучшее капиталовложение.
texts.en: Mayrambu is 58 years old and married.  Her family's primary business is fattening up and reselling livestock and farming.  Started in 1972, during the period of the Soviet Union, and with an initial sum of 120 Soviet rubles, this business currently yields about 10,000 so (KGS) per month.  At the present time, Mayrambu's family treats 1.74 hectares of irrigated land, where they grow potatoes and multi-year herbs.  In order to further increase livestock headcount, Mayrambu requested a loan in the sum of 40,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase additional livestock.  This will help her expand her business and increase livestock headcount and, thus, in her opinion, make a good capital investment.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock

loans.name: Cheta A Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Cheta A SHG Group in Western Kenya! Roselidah is the facilitator of the Cheta A SHG group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Roselidah takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to increase production and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Roselidah had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Roselidah was only able to harvest two bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Roselidah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Roselidah will educate her children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Cheta A SHG group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Roselidah with her group members and the field officer (who is standing on the far left).

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Upendo Farmers Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Upendo Farmers Group in Western Kenya! Night is the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Night takes care of four children. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Night had a very good maize yield harvesting six bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Night was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Night and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs such as fertilizer and seed is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which also includes training, credit, and insurance. With the income from maize sales, Night will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Upendo Farmers group will each plant between one half and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is married and has one child. She is 31 years old and lives in Camanga Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. 

Milagros owns and operates a gardening business venture in the agriculture sector to make a living.  She's been in this business for 5 years. Each month, she earns 8,800 PHP from her business. 

She requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional seed, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Milagros has been a member of GDMPC for almost two years. In the future, Milagros wants to make improvements to her house and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seed, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza De San Luis Group

texts.es:
Nueva Espernaza de San Luis es de la ciudad de Caaguazú, está integrado por 26 mujeres, quienes están en el cuarto ciclo del programa de mujeres emprendedoras. Ellas se unieron con el propósito de ayudarse las unas con las otras y de esa forma poder salir adelante por medio del trabajo en conjunto. Comentan que desean llegar al nivel máximo del programa de la fundación y de esa forma tener un mejor nivel de vida.
Francisca se define como una mujer muy trabajadora, ella se unió al grupo para poder trabajar con sus amigas y de esa forma ayudarse para que puedan mejorar sus estilos de vida. Dice que se dedica a la venta de carbón en lo cual le va muy bien, ya que este está siendo muy utilizado por las personas. Su trabajo la ayuda a mantener a su familia y también a cubrir los gastos que surgen día a día en la casa.
Ella solicita la ayuda de la fundación para la compra de carbón en cantidad, lo cual le será de mucha ayuda para poder tener en stock suficientes mercaderías para poder cumplir con sus clientes.
texts.en:
The “Nueva Esperanza de San Luis” (New Hope of St. Louis) communal bank is located in the city of Caaguazu, and is composed of 26 women who are in their 4th loan cycle in the “Program for Enterprising Women.” They meet with the proposition of helping one another and, in this way, to be able to get ahead by working together. The women comment that they wish to arrive at the maximum level of the Foundation's program, and thereby, to achieve a better standard of living.

Francisca is characterized as a very hard-working woman. She joined the group to be able to work with her friends and, in this way, to help them improve their style of life.  She reports that she sells charcoal and the business is going very well, since everyone uses it. Her work helps to maintain her family and, also, to cover daily household costs. Francisca is requesting the Foundation's help to buy charcoal in bulk. It will be much help to have a sufficient supply of merchandise in stock to be able to meet  customer demand.

loans.use: to buy charcoal in bulk for subsequent sale.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson is a 39-year-old married man. He and his wife Benter and they have children. He has been operating a fish-selling business for the last nine years earning a monthly income of KES 6,000.

He is requesting his second loan with KADET Ltd of KES 35,000 which he will use to buy more stocks of fish to sell. With the anticipated profits he will save to expand his business and venture into farming in his rural home.

His hopes and dreams are to expand his business into other localities and improve the living standard of the family.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Mauricio

texts.en:
Mauricio is 30 years old, and lives in Mexico city. He is single and lives in a house with his parents. He is a customer care executive at BBVA Bancomer Bank.

Unfortunately, Mauricio has recently had to be admitted to the hospital to receive treatment and asks for this loan to pay for the inpatient bills and pharmaceuticals that he needs in order to improve his health. $6,000 Mexican pesos will pay for the hospital expenses and the medication necessary for his complete treatment.

This is his second loan with Konfío and had no late payments for the duration of his first loan. Mauricio considers himself a highly responsible person when managing credits.

loans.use: to pay for inpatient hospital bills and medical examinations.

loans.name: Lauratu

texts.en:
Lauratu is 39 years old, married to a trader, and has four children. In 1999, Lauratu established her "gara" (locally dyed) textiles business. She began this business because she wanted to be self-employed and believed that she could earn enough income to help her husband provide a livelihood for their family. Working six days a week and 10 hours a day, Lauratu earns about 3,564,000 SLL a month. She makes good quality "gara" clothing and does her business by public transport twice in a month.  


Lauratu has already received and successfully repaid 5 loans, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase raw materials (ink, powder, white brillian). In the future, Lauratu plans to strengthen the business and give quality education to her children. She succeeded in helping her husband in up keeping the home.  She still plans to construct a house, open a saving account, pay her way for a pilgrimage to Mecca (Holy Land), and support her children's education. Lauratu is very determined and hopes to continue working hard to pay off her loans so that she can access more loans

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and dye for her business.

loans.name: Vasile

texts.en: Vasile and his wife, with their young daughter and small farm, live a typical rural Moldovan life. Their vineyards are their pride and joy. Set on a scenic hilltop overlooking the valley and town where he lives, they occupy his every day in the growing and harvesting seasons. His vision for expansion is to plant grapes of a different type - the popular Isabella grape, which is preferred by wineries. To make it happen, he is in need of capital for the purchase of new vines and the fertilizer to help assure successful growth.

loans.use: Vineyard Plantation

loans.name: Makalita

texts.en: Makalita has been raised in a farming family. Although she was the only girl in her family, her father never treated her separately from her brothers. She was trained by her father with some farming skills. But as she grew up, she realized that her brothers had better skills than her in running the farm. She then asked her brothers to help her grow taros so she can run a taro plantation. Her three brothers have always helped  their sister with her every need. She’s now married with 5 children, still running her taro plantation and selling fruit. She hopes to be able to provide her children with a better education rather than the farming skills that she had been taught by her father.

loans.use: Purchase organic fertilizers, pesticides, and knives

loans.name: Totoa

texts.en: Totoa is a 39-year-old mother from Vaimoso who runs a small shop. She was able to upgrade her shop with the assistance of SPBD; her first loan really attracted more clients. She has three children, and two of them are still relying on their mother for full support. She has managed to keep her business going and do her duties as a mother at home. She has done a good job, and as a result of her great effort, she is now able to earn more than ST$1,000(approximately USD$667) a week from her shop. She would like to use the loan to buy more supplies, like mutton flaps, turkey tails, and cigarettes.
